note.p: John Jones Pettus was Mississippi's governor during the first three years of the Civil War.

Born in Wilson County, Tennessee, on October 9, 1813, Pettus moved to Limestone County, Alabama, as a child. In 1835, he moved to Mississippi and eventually began a law practice in Scooba, Mississippi. He married Permelia Winston in the 1840s. She passed away in 1857, and in 1861 Pettus married Susan Hewell.

Pettus began pursuing a political career in the mid-1840s, first serving as a state representative for Kemper County. He won a state Senate election in 1848 and by 1853 had risen to president of the Mississippi Senate. Then, in January 1854, Governor Henry S. Foote resigned in protest before Governor-elect John J. McRae was inaugurated. Pettus’ position in the Senate placed him next in line to fill the governor’s vacancy, and he was sworn in as Mississippi’s interim executive on January 7, 1854. He served in that role for only three days, before McRae was inaugurated on January 10.

Pettus won the governor’s election in 1859. By that time, he had become a notable secessionist. He advocated for the creation of an independent Confederacy dedicated to preserving slavery. When Abraham Lincoln was elected president in 1860, Pettus called forth a special legislative session in Mississippi and pressed state representatives to hold a secession convention. His efforts succeeded, as such convention assembled in January 1861 and voted in support of secession, declaring the State of Mississippi out of the Union. Pettus won reelection for governor in 1861 and served until his term ended in 1863. Mississippi’s Constitution had a two-term limit for the governor’s office, leaving Pettus unable to run again. He took a commission as a colonel in the Mississippi State Troops and served until the end of the war. Shortly thereafter, Pettus moved to Arkansas. He applied for a presidential pardon according to President Andrew Johnson’s Reconstruction policies, but was denied three times.
Pettus died of pneumonia on January 25, 1867. He is buried in Flat Bayou Cemetery, Jefferson County, Arkansas.

catDesc.term: Railroads and Railroad Companies--Gulf and Ship Island Railroad (Gulfport, Miss.)

gloss.p: Headquartered in Gulfport, Mississippi, the Gulf and Ship Island Railroad was chartered in 1850, with a second charter issued in 1856, which lapsed due to financial constraints from the Civil War and a sparsely populated locality. A third charter was validated in 1882 and the rail company signed a six-year agreement to procure convicts from the Mississippi State Penitentiary to perform unpaid labor for the railroad company in 1884. Replacing chattel slavery with convict leasing, Mississippi's newly created laws channeled disproportionate numbers of Black people into the penitentiary and leased them to private companies like the Gulf and Ship Island Railroad Company to perform forced labor for the company's profit. They often subjected prisoners to brutal conditions and the mortality rates were high. Though earlier charters were issued, construction did not commence on the Gulf and Ship Island Railroad until 1887, when the first tracks were laid at Hattiesburg. By 1888, the Mississippi State Penitentiary canceled its convict-lease agreement with the company due to the brutal and inhumane treatment of convict laborers, alongside significant unpaid debt to the prison. Over 200 convicts went missing, either dead or escaped, throughout the agreement, with at least sixty accounted for as dead in 1888 alone. The public response to these numbers led the state to end its practice of leasing convicts to railroad companies in 1890. (Wikipedia; William Sturkey, "Race and Reconciliation on the Gulf & Ship Island Railroad," Southern Cultures, 87-104)

catDesc.term: Confederate States of America--General Land Office

gloss.p: Land offices were government organizations responsible for public lands, or property that fell within public domain. The United States government established a General Land Office in 1812 to handle federal territories in the west. The office oversaw surveys, districting, and the sale of public lands. The land office also negotiated and enforced lease contracts. State governments also established land offices to handle such matters for state-controlled land. (Wikipedia)

div.p:
Govr. J J Pettus
Jackson Mi

I have just finished making out the list of public land within the fifteen miles limits of the Gulf and Ship Island Rail Road & handed said list over to Genl. McLaurin the President of the said Rail Road comp=any & would respectfully ask that the land that has been so long withdrawn from sale be brought in market, as there are a great many applications to Enter within the limits withdrawn

Very Respectfully
your obt servant
J M Bradley Jr
Register

J M Bradley Esqr
Paulding Miss
April 16th
